home.home_introduction_body: The Chinese "Rightist" Archive is a database that holds historical files, testimonials, and images dated back to the mid 1950's. The Archive allows the public to search, learn, and explore a collection of over 40,000 data points, and growing, of "Rightist" victims and history from the 1957-1959 "Rightist" Movement in China.
home.home_history_body: The "Rightist" Movement was a two year period in China (1957-1959) where the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) reeducated, humiliated, imprisoned, and executed those who were counter-revolutionaries. Many of the victims of this movement were “early advocates of free-market reforms” and also many were chosen based off of participation during a prior campaign to this movement; the Hundred Flowers Campaign (factsanddetails.com, 2016). During the Hundred Flower Campaign (1956-1957), the Communist Party chairman, Mao Zedong, encouraged the citizens of China to speak up about the CCP in a controversial light and allowed “criticism of the government” (factsanddetails.com, 2016). Mao proposed the “idea o 'letting a hundred flowers bloom' in the arts and 'a hundred schools of thought contend' in the sciences" (factsanddetails.com, 2016). After receiving an overwhelming amount of criticism towards the CCP, Mao turned to punishing those who spoke out claiming it was due to their disloyalty to the CCP which caused disunity in their country, thus starting the "Rightist" movement. Although the "Rightist" Movement itself only lasted two years, the number of deaths has never been entirely confirmed and many who survived were imprisoned in labor camps years after the movement ended. This database is dedicated to educating the public about this movement and promoting human rights and social justice by showing the "rightists" who were victims of it.

about_movement.about_movement_introduction_body: The Anti-“Rightist” Movement was a two year period in China (1957-1959) where the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) reeducated, humiliated, imprisoned, and executed those who were counter-revolutionaries. Many of the victims of this movement were “early advocates of free-market reforms” and also many were chosen based off of participation during a prior campaign to this movement; the Hundred Flowers Campaign (factsanddetails.com, 2016). During the Hundred Flower Campaign (1956-1957), the Communist Party chairman, Mao Zedong, encouraged the citizens of China to speak up about the CCP in a controversial light and allowed “criticism of the government” (factsanddetails.com, 2016). Mao proposed the “idea o ‘letting a hundred flowers bloom’ in the arts and ‘a hundred schools of thought contend’ in the sciences' (factsanddetails.com, 2016). After receiving an overwhelming amount of criticism towards the CCP, Mao turned to punishing those who spoke out claiming it was due to their disloyalty to the CCP which caused disunity in their country, thus starting the Anti-'Rightist' movement. Although the Anti-'Rightist' Movement itself only lasted two years, the number of deaths has never been entirely confirmed and many who survived were imprisoned in labor camps years after the movement ended. This database is dedicated to educating the public about this movement and promoting human rights and social justice by showing the 'rightists' who were victims of it.
